author: tersec
content:
https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/blob/v1.0.0-alpha.9/src/engine/authentication.md#key-distribution seems inconsistent about whether JWT keys can be > 256 bits:
> The EL and CL clients MUST accept a cli/config parameter: jwt-secret, which designates a file containing the hex-encoded 256 bit secret key to be used for verifying/generating jwt tokens.
> 
> ...
> 
> If such a parameter is given, but the file cannot be read, or does not contain a hex-encoded key of at least 256 bits, the client should treat this as an error: either abort the startup, or show error and continue without exposing the authenticated port.

would a >256-bit JWT key be spec-compliant?

author: tersec
content: Regardless of what people think here, the spec should be clearer on this point -- either "at least" or not "at least" but not both

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Geth only allows secrets of exactly 32 byte, so we should change the second sentence imo

author: tersec
content: My preference as well. Theoretical, not-that-useful flexibility that's not well-tested is a liability

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> My preference as well, especially considering I'm almost certain their is no compelling reason for longer keys

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> approved. will leave it up for review for at least 24 hours. thanks!
